oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: McGill, J. Andrew, photographer
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Mt. Olivet Cemetery Confederate Circle
Confederate Circle, Mt. Olivet Cemetery, Nashville, Tennessee
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Park-like setting in which a stone obelisk topped with a uniformed soldier stands surrounded by a paved circular walkway, with two flags bearing the Confederate "stars and bars" planted on the lawn on either side of the walkway entrance. Various tombstones and a small mausoleum are also visible in the vicinity.

The Confederate Circle at Mt. Olivet Cemetery was created in 1869 as part of a reinterment project designed to honor approximately 1500 Confederate soldiers who died in and around Nashville during the Civil War. Members of the Ladies Memorial Society purchased a prominent location on a hill within the existing 1855 cemetery. Officials and dignitaries attended the dedication of the new burial ground on 9 May 1869, which was declared the local "Decoration Day" in Nashville. The program also encompassed a visit to decorate graves at the old City Cemetery, from which some of the dead were being transferred.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Mount Olivet Cemetery (Nashville, Tenn.); United States--History--Civil War, 1961-1865--Cemeteries--Confederate; Tombs and Sepulchral Monuments
The Persistence of Memory
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: Digital Initiatives, James E. Walker Library, Middle Tennessee State University
